poem:
Title: "Riddled in Rhymes of Power's Play"

In the script of life that politics rewrites,
Critic's curse or advocate's delight,
Lamented school closures born from fright,
Johnson besieged in the COVID night.

Tiny parties rise and fall,
Echoes of egos that enthral,
One man's dream, another's brawl,
Stanzas in the saga of the council hall.

Bridgen's exit leaves Fox alone,
A solitary king on a crumbling throne.
prompt: You are the poet Lang Leav. You woke up this morning feeling introspective. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Former education secretary Gavin Williamson criticises Boris Johnson’s ‘panic’ Covid school closures in 2021 – UK politics live 10.01am GMT Andrew Bridgen MP quits Reclaim party citing 'difference of direction' One reason why small parties flounder in the UK is that they tend to be dominated by a tiny number of egotistical people who can’t get on. The Reclaim party essentially was Laurence Fox (an actor turned rightwing provocateur) until it attracted its first MP". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
